9.17.22  2:33 am   I came up with a melody I really like, but I feel like I've heard it somewhere before, and I'm not entirely sure where. Even if I haven't heard it, though, I feel like it's simple enough that somebody must have used it somewhere already. So my question is basically how do I make sure I'm not totally ripping off somebody else's melody by accident?

Â Â Â Â Â  the best way to find out is to get a #1 hit with it. then the original owners (and 100 other people also claiming to own it) will contact you

Â Â Â Â Â when the camera swung around to that location, there was already some text sitting there that said "respect me", from earlier, and so i took it as an opportunity to switch it to something a princess might say

9.16.22  8:26 pm   in your most recent song, is "pave the way" to "another/some other time" about trying to make something good but putting it off until someone beats you to it, then feeling like it's useless because "it's already been paved today, we don't have to pave it again"?

Â Â Â Â Â  no. "pave the way" is about bravely moving toward the future. then, the second time, "it's already been paved today" came about because i was 80% sure that i wanted to do that chorus again right there, but the problem is that that "pave the way" line seems to be most effective when it feels "new". the line seemed to lose its effectiveness when being said the second time. But i found that by dropping down to a lower range and going "it's already been paved today", it made the whole thing land better and solved that problem

Â Â Â Â Â  it makes me feel powerful

9.16.22  2:57 am   Why are chords 2m and 4 in a key sort of like siblings?

Â Â Â Â Â they sound similar. if you are writing music, i think you'll very often find yourself in a situation where either one of those will work, but one or the other may be slightly better

     Are there any other chords are also related in a similar way?

Â Â Â Â Â sure. 1 and 6m. sometimes 5 and 3m. perhaps b6 and 4m. All of these pairs of chords seem to generally fit in the same spots as each other, but the relative minor will usually have a more somber and subdued sound, while the relative major will sound a little more direct and bold

9.15.22  8:18 pm   Hi, Bill Wurtz. I've been really enjoying "where i've been." Would you mind telling me what the time signature is from "let me tell you a fable" to "let me wander away from it"?

Â Â Â Â Â  the denominator stays constant (4), and the top number, the way i feel it, one bar at a time, would go something like this: 3,3,2,4,4,4,3,2,3,2,4. Now that i see it, it looks like a lot of these would cancel out to steady 4's, so if you're brave enough to plow right through, i suppose you could get by with all 4s until a 2 at the very end, and that would even line up correctly with the break in the middle. this is purely a coincidence
